Based on my search results, I can provide comprehensive information about theater productions, radio drama adaptations, and stage performances of Bolesław Prus's "Lalka" (The Doll).

## Film and Television Adaptations

Lalka has been adapted for screen multiple times, including a 1977 TV serial directed by Ryszard Ber and a 1968 film directed by Wojciech Jerzy Has. There's also a digitally reconstructed version of the TV series available.

## Theater Productions

The novel has been adapted for stage numerous times:

In 1952, there was a theatrical production at Warsaw's Polish Theatre directed by Zygmunt Leśnodorski, with Lech Madaliński as Wokulski and Nina Andrycz as Izabela.

In 1967, Warsaw's Powszechny Theatre presented "Pan Wokulski according to Lalka by Bolesław Prus" directed by Adam Hanuszkiewicz, with Mariusz Dmochowski as Wokulski and Ewa Wawrzoń as Izabela.

More recent productions include:
- 1993: "Panna Izabela according to Lalka by Bolesław Prus" at Warsaw's National Theatre, directed by Adam Hanuszkiewicz
- 2008: Production at Wrocław's Polish Theatre directed by Wiktor Rubin
- 2010: A musical at Gdynia's Musical Theatre directed by Wojciech Kościelniak(no content)Currently, there's a contemporary adaptation at Kraków's Słowacki Theatre directed by Wojtek Klemm, which qualified for the "Living Classics" competition for staging classical Polish literature.

## Radio Drama Adaptations

The first radio adaptation was in 1937, featuring the "Old Clerk" fragment adapted by Witold Hulewicz.

More recently, Radio Katowice has produced an audio series of Lalka with a star-studded cast, broadcasting Monday to Friday at 12:30 and Sundays at 22:05. This modern adaptation features Adam Woronowicz as Wokulski and Julia Wieniawa, presented as a 13-episode series with a contemporary approach and modern soundtrack.

## Cultural Impact

Millions of Poles have read Lalka, and film and television adaptations have attracted large audiences throughout the 20th century. The Doll has been translated into twenty-eight languages, demonstrating its international appeal.

The adaptations consistently aim to make this classic work relevant to contemporary audiences while maintaining its literary integrity and exploring themes that remain current today.
